title: Industry-Specific Guide
subtitle: What to expect and find in different facility types
description: Comprehensive guide to industry-specific energy efficiency opportunities: equipment types, common issues, typical savings, and what to look for during site visits in manufacturing, healthcare, retail, office, warehouse, data centers, hospitality, education, and other facility types.

cards.title: Manufacturing
cards.description: Compressed air, process heating, motors, steam systems, refrigeration. High energy intensity, 24/7 operations.

cards.title: Healthcare
cards.description: HVAC load, 24/7 operations, strict environmental controls, sterilization equipment, lighting.

cards.title: Retail
cards.description: Lighting (interior + exterior), HVAC, refrigeration (coolers/freezers), plug loads, long operating hours.

cards.title: Office Buildings
cards.description: HVAC, lighting, plug loads, building envelope, occupancy patterns, tenant spaces.

cards.title: Warehouses
cards.description: High-bay lighting, minimal HVAC, dock doors, refrigeration (if food distribution), material handling equipment.

cards.title: Data Centers
cards.description: CRAC units, UPS systems, IT load, cooling efficiency, PUE metrics, redundancy systems.

cards.title: Hospitality
cards.description: Guest room HVAC, common area lighting, commercial kitchens, laundry, pools/spas, 24/7 operations.

cards.title: K-12 Public Schools
cards.description: Elementary, middle, high schools. HVAC scheduling, lighting, gymnasiums, cafeterias, variable occupancy.

cards.title: K-12 Private Schools
cards.description: Private elementary, middle, high schools. Similar to public but often different funding and priorities.

cards.title: Universities
cards.description: Large campuses, research facilities, dorms, dining halls, labs, libraries, 24/7 operations in some areas.

cards.title: Colleges
cards.description: Smaller campuses, community colleges, vocational schools. Classrooms, labs, common areas, variable occupancy.

cards.title: Food Service
cards.description: Commercial kitchens (ovens, fryers, hoods), refrigeration, HVAC, lighting, hot water, exhaust systems.

content.content:
## What to Expect

Each industry has distinct energy consumption patterns, equipment types, and operational requirements. This guide helps you:

- **Identify opportunities quickly** during site visits
- **Speak the language** of each industry
- **Prioritize measures** based on typical savings and feasibility
- **Ask the right questions** to uncover hidden opportunities

**Key Principle:** The same technology (e.g., LED lighting) may have different value propositions depending on operating hours, operational constraints, and utility rates.

sections.title: Manufacturing Facilities
sections.subtitle: Industrial processes, compressed air, process heating

content.content:
## Manufacturing Facilities

**Energy Profile:** Typically the highest energy intensity of all building types. Operations often run 24/7 with heavy process loads.

**Key Characteristics:**
- High base loads (process equipment rarely shuts off)
- Multiple energy systems (compressed air, process heating, steam, motors)
- Significant demand charges
- Often eligible for industrial utility programs

**Typical Energy Split:**
- Process loads: 50‚Äì70% (compressed air, process heating, motors)
- HVAC: 10‚Äì25%
- Lighting: 5‚Äì15%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

content.caption: Manufacturing Equipment & Opportunities

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are your operating hours? (24/7, 3 shifts, single shift?)
- Do you have peak demand issues? What's your typical peak kW?
- Are there process loads that could be shifted?

**Compressed Air:**
- How many compressors do you have? Are they always running?
- Do you have compressed air leaks? (Easy to identify: listen for hissing, look for unconnected hoses)
- What's your typical compressed air pressure? Could you reduce it?

**Process Heating:**
- What temperatures are required? Can they be optimized?
- Do you vent hot air/exhaust that could be recovered?
- Are furnaces/ovens insulated properly?

**Motors:**
- Do you have motors that run continuously but could be controlled?
- Are there applications with variable loads that don't have VFDs?

**Utilities:**
- What utility rate are you on? (Industrial rates often have high demand charges)
- Are you eligible for any industrial efficiency programs?

Check compressor room: multiple compressors running simultaneously?
Feel pipes: hot uninsulated steam/process pipes?
Check motor nameplates: efficiency ratings, sizes
Look for VFDs on variable load motors (fans, pumps, compressors)
Identify process heating equipment (furnaces, ovens, kilns)

Check boiler room: age, efficiency ratings, insulation
Note operating hours and shift patterns

content.content:
## Healthcare Facilities

**Energy Profile:** 24/7 operations with strict environmental controls. HVAC is typically the largest load.

**Key Characteristics:**
- Continuous operation (hospitals never shut down)
- Strict temperature, humidity, and air quality requirements
- High outside air requirements (infection control)
- Multiple HVAC zones with different requirements
- Significant lighting loads (especially in older facilities)

**Typical Energy Split:**
- HVAC: 50‚Äì65%
- Lighting: 10‚Äì20%
- Medical equipment: 5‚Äì10%
- Sterilization/laundry: 5‚Äì10%
- Other: 10‚Äì15%

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are your peak demand charges? (Hospitals often have high demand)
- Are there areas that operate 24/7 vs. normal business hours?
- What are your temperature/humidity setpoints? (Can they be optimized within code requirements?)

**HVAC:**
- How old are your chillers/boilers? When were they last upgraded?
- Do you have economizers? Are they working properly?
- Are you using outside air for cooling when available?
- Do you have VFDs on pumps and fans?

**Lighting:**
- What types of lighting are in patient rooms, hallways, operating rooms?
- Are there controls (occupancy, scheduling, daylight)?
- What are the operating hours for different areas?

**Special Considerations:**
- Healthcare facilities often have capital constraints but long-term planning horizons
- ROI requirements may be longer (5‚Äì10 years) due to operational priorities
- Patient comfort and safety are paramount‚Äîchanges must not compromise operations

content.content:
## Retail Facilities

**Energy Profile:** Lighting and HVAC are typically the largest loads, with significant refrigeration in grocery/convenience stores.

**Key Characteristics:**
- Long operating hours (often 12‚Äì16 hours/day, some 24/7)
- High lighting requirements (ambient + accent lighting)
- Significant refrigeration load in food retail
- Variable occupancy (higher during business hours)
- Exterior lighting for parking lots and signage

**Typical Energy Split (Non-Food Retail):**
- Lighting: 35‚Äì50%
- HVAC: 30‚Äì45%
- Plug loads: 10‚Äì15%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

**Typical Energy Split (Food Retail):**
- Refrigeration: 35‚Äì50%
- Lighting: 20‚Äì30%
- HVAC: 15‚Äì25%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

content.caption: Retail Equipment & Opportunities

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are your store hours? (Some retailers operate 24/7)
- Are there areas that could have reduced lighting when closed?
- Do you have peak demand charges?

**Lighting:**
- What types of lighting are used? (Fluorescent, halogen, LED?)
- Are there controls (occupancy, scheduling, dimming)?
- What about exterior lighting and signage?

**Refrigeration (Food Retail):**
- How old are your refrigeration systems?
- Do coolers/freezers have doors? (Open cases use much more energy)
- Are there opportunities for floating head pressure?
- Is there subcooling or heat recovery?

**HVAC:**
- What type of HVAC? (Packaged rooftop units are common)
- Are there economizers?
- Are there controls for different zones?
- What are temperature setpoints? (Can they be optimized?)

**Financial:**
- Retailers often prioritize quick payback (2‚Äì4 years)
- ROI calculations should include maintenance savings (especially for lighting)
- Chain stores may have standardized requirements

content.content:
## Office Buildings

**Energy Profile:** HVAC and lighting are typically the largest loads, with significant plug loads from computers and equipment.

**Key Characteristics:**
- Business hours operation (typically 8‚Äì12 hours/day, 5‚Äì7 days/week)
- Variable occupancy (higher during business hours, lower at night/weekends)
- Multiple tenants in some buildings (coordination challenges)
- Comfort-focused (temperature, lighting quality important)
- Often have data centers/server rooms

**Typical Energy Split:**
- HVAC: 40‚Äì55%
- Lighting: 20‚Äì30%
- Plug loads: 15‚Äì25%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are your business hours? (Extended hours vs. standard 8‚Äì5?)
- What's your occupancy pattern? (Higher during certain times?)
- Are there tenant spaces? (Coordination required)
- Do you have a data center or server room?

**HVAC:**
- How old are your chillers/boilers?
- Do you have economizers? Are they working?
- Are there VFDs on pumps and fans?
- What are temperature setpoints? (Can they be optimized?)
- Is HVAC running 24/7 or only during business hours?

**Lighting:**
- What types of lighting? (Fluorescent, LED?)
- Are there controls (occupancy, scheduling, daylight)?
- Do you have windows for daylighting?

**Building Envelope:**
- How old is the building?
- Are there single-pane windows? (Upgrade to double/triple pane)
- Is there insulation? (Check walls, roof)
- Are there air leaks? (Drafty areas?)

**Financial:**
- Office buildings often prioritize tenant comfort and property value
- ROI may be longer (5‚Äì7 years) but improvements can increase property value
- Energy savings translate to lower operating expenses

content.content:
## Warehouses & Distribution Centers

**Energy Profile:** Lighting is typically the largest load, with minimal HVAC (often just heating for worker comfort). Refrigeration may be significant if storing food products.

**Key Characteristics:**
- High ceilings (30‚Äì50+ feet)
- Large open spaces
- Long operating hours (often 16‚Äì24 hours/day)
- Minimal HVAC (often just heating in cold climates)
- Frequent dock door openings (air infiltration)
- Forklifts and material handling equipment

**Typical Energy Split (Dry Warehouse):**
- Lighting: 60‚Äì80%
- HVAC: 10‚Äì25%
- Material handling: 5‚Äì15%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

**Typical Energy Split (Cold Storage):**
- Refrigeration: 50‚Äì70%
- Lighting: 15‚Äì25%
- HVAC: 5‚Äì15%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are your operating hours? (Many warehouses run 16‚Äì24 hours/day)
- What's your ceiling height? (Affects lighting requirements)
- Do you have cold storage?
- How many dock doors? How frequently are they open?

**Lighting:**
- What types of high-bay lighting? (HID, MH, LED?)
- Are there controls? (Occupancy sensors challenging with high ceilings, but scheduling works)
- What are the mounting heights?
- Are there different zones with different requirements?

**HVAC:**
- Do you have HVAC? (Many warehouses have minimal HVAC)
- Is it just heating for worker comfort?
- Are there controls?
- What are temperature setpoints?

**Dock Doors:**
- Do you have dock seals/shelters?
- How often are doors open?
- Is there air infiltration? (Drafty areas?)

**Refrigeration (Cold Storage):**
- How old are refrigeration systems?
- What temperatures are maintained?
- Is there floating head pressure?
- How's the insulation?

**Financial:**
- Warehouses often prioritize quick payback (2‚Äì4 years)
- Lighting retrofits typically have excellent ROI due to long hours and high-bay costs

sections.title: Data Centers
sections.subtitle: Server rooms, data centers, IT facilities

content.content:
## Data Centers

**Energy Profile:** Cooling and IT equipment are the largest loads. Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE) is the key metric.

**Key Characteristics:**
- 24/7 operation
- Critical uptime requirements
- High power density
- Redundant systems (power, cooling)
- Strict environmental controls (temperature, humidity)
- PUE target: < 1.5 (best-in-class < 1.2)

**Typical Energy Split:**
- IT Equipment: 40‚Äì60%
- Cooling: 30‚Äì50%
- Power Distribution/UPS: 5‚Äì15%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

Lack of air/water economizers, not using outside air when available
Hot/cold aisle mixing, lack of containment, poor air distribution
Older UPS, low efficiency, oversized capacity, lack of modular systems
Old transformers, inefficient PDUs, lack of monitoring
Old servers, lack of virtualization, inefficient hardware
Lack of DCIM, poor visibility, manual operation
content.caption: Data Center Equipment & Opportunities

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Metrics:**
- What's your current PUE? (Power Usage Effectiveness)
- What's your IT load? (kW)
- What are your energy costs? (Often significant)

**Cooling:**
- What type of cooling? (CRAC, CRAH, chilled water, direct expansion?)
- Do you have economizers? (Air or water economization?)
- What are temperature/humidity setpoints? (Can they be optimized?)
- Is there hot/cold aisle containment?
- How's airflow management? (Mixing issues?)

**Power:**
- What type of UPS? (Age, efficiency, capacity?)
- Is UPS oversized? (Common issue)
- What's power distribution efficiency?

**Operations:**
- Is there a DCIM (Data Center Infrastructure Management) system?
- What's the redundancy level? (N, N+1, 2N?)
- Are there opportunities for consolidation/virtualization?

**Financial:**
- Data centers prioritize uptime and reliability
- Energy efficiency improvements can be significant due to high loads
- PUE improvements are a key selling point
- ROI calculations should account for both energy and operational benefits

**Energy Profile:** HVAC and lighting are typically the largest loads, with significant energy use in kitchens and laundry.

**Key Characteristics:**
- 24/7 operations
- Variable occupancy (guest rooms)
- Multiple building types (guest rooms, common areas, kitchens, pools)
- High comfort expectations
- Significant hot water use

**Typical Energy Split:**
- HVAC: 35‚Äì50%
- Lighting: 15‚Äì25%
- Hot Water: 10‚Äì20%
- Kitchen: 10‚Äì15%
- Laundry: 5‚Äì10%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

content.content:
## K-12 Public Schools

**Energy Profile:** HVAC and lighting are typically the largest loads, with variable occupancy patterns. Public schools often have tight budgets and must follow state regulations.

**Key Characteristics:**
- Variable occupancy (high during school hours, low at night/weekends/holidays)
- Seasonal operation (many schools closed in summer, some have summer programs)
- Multiple building types (classrooms, gymnasiums, cafeterias, libraries)
- Budget constraints (public funding, bond measures)
- State and district regulations
- Often older buildings (built 1950s-1980s)
- Pools common in high schools

**Typical Energy Split:**
- HVAC: 40‚Äì55%
- Lighting: 20‚Äì30%
- Plug loads: 10‚Äì20%
- Other: 10‚Äì15%

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are operating hours? (School day vs. extended hours?)
- Are there summer programs? (Affects seasonal operation and HVAC scheduling)
- What building types? (Elementary, middle, high school?)
- Do you have pools? (Common in high schools)
- How many students? (Affects load sizing)

**HVAC:**
- How old are HVAC systems? (Many public schools have 20+ year old systems)
- Are there controls? (Scheduling critical for variable occupancy)
- Do you have economizers?
- What are temperature setpoints? (Often fixed, can they be optimized?)
- Is HVAC running during unoccupied periods? (Common issue)
- Are there different zones? (Classrooms vs. gyms vs. offices)

**Lighting:**
- What types of lighting? (Fluorescent, LED?)
- Are there controls? (Scheduling, occupancy, daylight?)
- Do you have gymnasiums? (High-bay lighting opportunities)
- Are there windows for daylighting?

**Building Envelope:**
- How old is the building? (Older schools may have poor insulation)
- Are there single-pane windows? (Common in older buildings)
- Is there air leakage? (Drafty areas?)

**Financial:**
- Public schools often have tight budgets and long approval processes
- Energy savings free up funds for educational programs
- ROI requirements may be longer (5‚Äì7 years)
- State and utility programs may be available (e.g., Prop 39 in California)
- Bond measures may fund energy efficiency projects

sections.title: K-12 Private Schools
sections.subtitle: Private elementary, middle, and high schools

content.content:
## K-12 Private Schools

**Energy Profile:** Similar to public schools but often with different priorities and funding sources. May have more flexibility in decision-making.

**Key Characteristics:**
- Variable occupancy (high during school hours, low at night/weekends/holidays)
- Seasonal operation (many closed in summer, some have summer programs)
- Multiple building types (classrooms, gymnasiums, cafeterias, libraries, chapels)
- Tuition-based funding (may have different budget priorities)
- Often smaller class sizes and facilities
- May have religious or specialized programs
- Often newer or better-maintained facilities than public schools

**Typical Energy Split:**
- HVAC: 40‚Äì55%
- Lighting: 20‚Äì30%
- Plug loads: 10‚Äì20%
- Other: 10‚Äì15%

content.content:
## Universities

**Energy Profile:** Large, complex campuses with diverse building types. HVAC and lighting are major loads, with significant research facility loads.

**Key Characteristics:**
- Large campuses (multiple buildings, central plants)
- 24/7 operations in some areas (dorms, research labs, libraries)
- Variable occupancy (classrooms vs. dorms vs. labs)
- Research facilities (high energy intensity, specialized HVAC)
- Dormitories (residential-like loads, 24/7)
- Dining halls (commercial kitchens)
- Central plants (chilled water, steam, hot water)
- Sustainability goals (many have carbon neutrality targets)

**Typical Energy Split:**
- HVAC: 40‚Äì50%
- Lighting: 15‚Äì25%
- Research/Plug loads: 15‚Äì25%
- Other: 10‚Äì15%

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- How large is the campus? (Number of buildings, square footage?)
- What are operating hours for different building types? (Classrooms vs. dorms vs. labs?)
- Do you have a central plant? (Chilled water, steam?)
- What are your sustainability goals? (Carbon neutrality targets?)

**Central Plant:**
- How old are chillers/boilers?
- Is there optimization/sequencing?
- What's the efficiency of the central plant?
- Are there opportunities for heat recovery?

**HVAC:**
- How old are HVAC systems across campus?
- Are there controls? (Scheduling critical for variable occupancy)
- Do you have economizers?
- What are temperature setpoints?
- Is HVAC running during unoccupied periods?

**Research Labs:**
- How many fume hoods?
- Are fume hoods controlled? (Variable air volume?)
- What are ventilation rates?
- Are there opportunities to reduce ventilation when unoccupied?

**Dormitories:**
- What type of HVAC? (PTAC units common)
- Are there controls? (Occupancy-based controls can save significant energy)
- How many dorm rooms?

**Financial:**
- Universities often have sustainability goals that support energy efficiency
- Large campuses allow for economies of scale
- ROI requirements may be longer (5‚Äì10 years) but improvements support sustainability goals
- May have access to green bonds or sustainability funding

sections.title: Colleges & Community Colleges
sections.subtitle: Community colleges, vocational schools, smaller campuses

content.content:
## Colleges & Community Colleges

**Energy Profile:** Smaller campuses than universities, but similar energy patterns. HVAC and lighting are major loads.

**Key Characteristics:**
- Smaller campuses (fewer buildings than universities)
- Variable occupancy (classrooms, labs, common areas)
- May have vocational programs (specialized equipment)
- Community colleges often have tight budgets
- May have evening/weekend programs (extended hours)
- Often commuter-based (less 24/7 operation than universities)
- May have specialized facilities (auto shops, welding, culinary)

**Typical Energy Split:**
- HVAC: 40‚Äì55%
- Lighting: 20‚Äì30%
- Plug loads: 10‚Äì20%
- Vocational equipment: 5‚Äì15% (if applicable)
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are operating hours? (Day vs. evening/weekend programs?)
- What programs do you offer? (Vocational programs may have specialized equipment)
- How many buildings? (Smaller campuses than universities)
- Do you have specialized facilities? (Auto shops, welding, culinary, etc.)

**HVAC:**
- How old are HVAC systems?
- Are there controls? (Scheduling critical for variable occupancy)
- Do you have economizers?
- What are temperature setpoints? (Can they be optimized?)
- Is HVAC running during unoccupied periods?

**Lighting:**
- What types of lighting? (Fluorescent, LED?)
- Are there controls? (Scheduling, occupancy, daylight?)
- Do you have specialized lighting needs? (Vocational programs)
- Are there windows for daylighting?

**Vocational Equipment:**
- What types of equipment? (Welding, auto shop, etc.)
- Are there controls? (Many run constantly)
- What are the energy requirements?

**Building Envelope:**
- How old is the building?
- Are there single-pane windows?
- Is there air leakage?

**Financial:**
- Community colleges often have tight budgets
- Energy savings free up funds for educational programs
- ROI requirements may be longer (5‚Äì7 years)
- May have access to state and utility programs

## Food Service Facilities

**Energy Profile:** Kitchen equipment, HVAC, and refrigeration are typically the largest loads.

**Key Characteristics:**
- High heat loads from cooking equipment
- Significant ventilation requirements (hoods)
- Refrigeration for food storage
- Long operating hours (often 12‚Äì16 hours/day)
- High hot water use
- Comfort requirements (dining areas)

**Typical Energy Split:**
- Kitchen Equipment: 25‚Äì35%
- HVAC: 20‚Äì30%
- Refrigeration: 15‚Äì25%
- Lighting: 10‚Äì15%
- Hot Water: 10‚Äì15%
- Other: 5‚Äì10%

content.content:
## Key Questions to Ask

**Operations:**
- What are operating hours?
- What type of cuisine? (Affects equipment types)
- Do you have dining areas? (Affects HVAC needs)

**Kitchen Equipment:**
- How old is kitchen equipment? (Ovens, fryers, grills, etc.)
- Are there controls? (Many systems run constantly)
- What's the efficiency of burners/equipment?

**Ventilation:**
- What type of hoods? (Type I, Type II?)
- Are hoods controlled? (Many run constantly)
- Are hoods oversized? (Common issue)
- What's the exhaust fan efficiency?

**HVAC:**
- How is HVAC sized? (Often oversized due to kitchen heat)
- Are there controls?
- Is there make-up air for kitchen exhaust?
- What are temperature setpoints?

**Refrigeration:**
- How old are walk-ins and reach-ins?
- Do they have doors? (Open cases use much more energy)
- What's the maintenance history?

**Hot Water:**
- How is hot water generated? (Often high demand in kitchens)
- Are there recirculation controls?

**Financial:**
- Food service facilities often prioritize quick payback (2‚Äì4 years)
- Kitchen equipment upgrades can have significant energy and operational benefits
- Ventilation improvements can improve comfort and reduce energy

content.content:
## Cross-Industry Patterns

While each industry has unique characteristics, there are common patterns:

### Universal Opportunities
- **Lighting:** LED retrofits with controls are valuable in almost every industry
- **HVAC Controls:** Scheduling, economizers, and VFDs apply broadly
- **Building Envelope:** Insulation and air sealing benefit most facilities

### High-Value Quick Wins
1. **LED Lighting + Controls** (especially in facilities with long operating hours)
2. **HVAC Optimization** (scheduling, economizers, VFDs)
3. **Compressed Air** (manufacturing-specific, but huge opportunity)
4. **Refrigeration** (food-related facilities)

### Industry-Specific Priorities
- **Manufacturing:** Compressed air, process heating, motors
- **Healthcare:** HVAC optimization, lighting, 24/7 operations
- **Retail:** Lighting, HVAC, refrigeration (food retail)
- **Office:** HVAC, lighting, building envelope
- **Warehouse:** High-bay lighting, dock doors
- **Data Center:** Cooling efficiency, PUE improvements
- **Hospitality:** Guest room HVAC, kitchen, laundry
- **K-12 Schools:** HVAC scheduling, lighting, variable occupancy
- **Universities:** Central plants, research labs, dormitories
- **Colleges:** HVAC, lighting, vocational equipment
- **Food Service:** Kitchen equipment, ventilation, refrigeration

## Universal Questions to Ask

Regardless of industry, these questions help identify opportunities:

1. **Operating Hours:** When is the facility occupied? (Affects lighting, HVAC scheduling)
2. **Peak Demand:** Do you have high demand charges? (Affects battery storage, load shifting)
3. **Equipment Age:** How old are major systems? (HVAC, lighting, process equipment)
4. **Controls:** Do you have energy management systems or controls? (Scheduling, occupancy, etc.)
5. **Maintenance:** What's your maintenance budget? (Energy efficiency can reduce maintenance)
6. **Comfort Issues:** Are there comfort complaints? (Often indicates inefficiency)
7. **Future Plans:** Are there planned renovations or expansions? (Opportunity to bundle improvements)
8. **Utility Programs:** Are you aware of utility rebates/programs? (Can improve ROI)

## Field Visit Approach

**Before the Visit:**
- Research the industry type and typical opportunities
- Review utility bills if available
- Prepare industry-specific questions

**During the Visit:**
- Start with a facility tour to understand operations
- Ask discovery questions (operating hours, pain points, equipment age)
- Identify equipment types and ages
- Look for obvious inefficiencies (leaks, old equipment, lack of controls)
- Take photos and notes

**After the Visit:**
- Prioritize opportunities by savings potential and feasibility
- Consider utility rebates and programs
- Develop recommendations with clear ROI
- Present quick wins first, then deeper measures

content.quote: Every facility is unique, but industry knowledge helps you ask the right questions and identify opportunities quickly. Start with quick wins, then go deeper.
